node.title: Rare encounter with 'grumpy' frog has spotters jumping for joy
node.description: AÂ burrowing frog that can stay underground for years has come above ground to play after strong November rain in outback Queensland.
node.content:
["The sound of frogs croaking is so loud, you would have to raise your voice to hold a conversation.", "While that may be par for the course in a tropical forest, this chorus of croaks is occurring on the edge of the Simpson Desert in outback Queensland.", "Among this army of frogs, which only appear under\u00a0the most ideal conditions, is the elusive Desert Spadefoot\u00a0(Notaden nichollsi), with its unmistakeable 'grumpy' expression.", "This angry-looking amphibian isn't really hopping mad.", "It's just making the most of the warm, wet weather to feed and breed.", "", "
Conditions have to be just right to entice a Desert Spadefoot to the surface; not too hot, not too cold, and plenty of rain.\u00a0(Supplied: Helene Aubault)
", "
Wetlands come to life
", "The raucous ribbits are music to the ears of Ethabuka Reserve manager\u00a0Helene Aubault, who only gets to see burrowing ground frogs in far western Queensland once a year if she's lucky.", "Most of the year, the reserve is semi-arid, dry, red dunes for as far as the eye can see, but 74 millimetres of rain in mid-November has brought the wetlands to life, and the frogs to the surface.", "\"We rarely see them;\u00a0they only come out once every now and then, once there is enough rain,\" Dr Aubault said.", "\"We've often been out when it rains, so I've been very unlucky ...\u00a0it was quite exciting to see them.", "\"We have not seen frogs for a year and a half.\"", "
If 'Grumpy Cat' was a frog
", "Given how infrequently burrowing frogs can surface to enjoy the warm and wet conditions after substantial rain north-west of Bedourie, the sights and sounds of any of Kermit's cousins puts smiles on faces.", "But the Desert Spadefoot stands out, despite blending in nicely with the muddy conditions it thrives in", "\"They look like a grumpy frog. You know the grumpy cat? It's the equivalent of the grumpy frog,\" Dr\u00a0Aubault said.", "", "
The\u00a0Common Spadefoot\u00a0is another burrowing frog species that only emerge from time to time.(Supplied: Helene Aubault)
", "\"They have a lot of skin and are quite fat. They're not slimy, they're a bit different;\u00a0they're very funny.", "\"They're a pretty amazing frog;\u00a0to avoid any drought they just burrow underground. They have a massive gland of water under their skin, so they just fill that, burrow under the ground, stay there for months or years even until it rains enough, and recently it has rained enough.", "\"Then they emerge, and breed and eat straight away, and once the water is too low, they go back inside.\"", "", "
George Madani has visited the Simpson Desert twenty times in the past decade.(Supplied: George Madani)
", "Independent wildlife ecologist George Madani\u00a0knows just how lucky you must be to see frogs in the desert, having\u00a0visited the Simpson Desert\u00a0twenty times in the past decade.", "Mr Madani is particularly excited to have identified the sound of a member of the\u00a0Cyclorana group\u00a0of frogs in videos shared by Bush Heritage of the Ethabuka Reserve.", "\"Their breeding conditions are very ephemeral, rely on erratic rainfall, and need a lot of rain for them to come out, and when they do emerge, conditions are so wet that you yourself cannot get out there,\" Mr Madani said.", "\"Other than one occasion, I've not come across the Cyclorana species of frogs. I wish I was out there.", "", "
Gwenealle Barton splashes\u00a0around after Ethabuka Reserve received 74mm in two days on the 10th and 11th of November.(Supplied: Helene Aubault)
"]
